title: How Much Does Your Credit Score Matter? | Merryn Talks Money

rawLines.text: [Music]
Bloomberg Audio Studios podcasts, radio,
news.
Welcome to Marin Talks Your Money, the
personal finance edition of Marin Talks
Money. In these bonus podcasts, we talk
about the best strategies for making the
most of your money. I'm Maron Samset
Webb and with me senior reporter and
money distilled author John Steek. Hi
John.
Hi Mar.
Right, this week we are tackling a topic
suggested by Tala, an apprentice here at
Bloomberg who's been working on our team
the last few months. Tala is in her
early 20s and says the surprisingly
frequent topic among her friends is
credit scores.
I don't really have a credit history
yet. How would my credit score be
determined?
What factors go into determining my
credit score? And how do I even check my
credit score? I've noticed that when I
check my credit score on different
websites, they vary. Why is that?
I'm a bit lost by this one. I literally
do not remember ever talking about
credit scores in my 20ies, John.
Um, no. But then we were privileged cuz
the '9s were a much better time for
young people in general. We didn't have
to worry about money, did we? Really,
cuz everything was so cheap.
Yeah, we could buy houses.
Yeah, we could buy houses.
On the plus side, the fact that that
Tyler and her friends are caring about
credit scores, maybe they're taking out
mortgages. We'll talk about that later.
Anyway, so the question is, how do
credit scores work? What are they? Do I
have one? Do I have several? How
important is it? What does it mean? What
affects it the most? And how do I make
it good? So, lots of questions here,
some of which John and I could answer
alone, some of which we quite clearly
couldn't. So, we brought an expert to
help us go through all the basics of
this subject, John Webb. John is the
senior consumer affairs manager at
Experian. John, thank you so much for
joining us today.
Oh, glad to join. So right back at the
beginning, what is a credit score?
There is not one credit score. So your
credit score is a number that is given
to you by a credit reference agency like
Experian and there are others as well.
Equifax and TransUnion are the other
two. So there's three main credit
reference agencies and we will all give
you a number and it's a summary of the
performance of your credit report. So
all the information that's on there, how
you've managed credit in the past 6
years or so and how much debt you are in
for example right now and the number
gives you a good indication of how a
lender will judge the information on
your credit report when you apply for
credit.
Okay, so this is a number. What is a
good number and what is a bad number?
Well, that's an interesting question
because there is not one credit score.
Don't judge the numbers side by side.
Each credit reference agency will give
you their own experiences out of 999.
So we will give you a banding to say you
know somewhere along the lines of you're
somewhere in the good or very good or
excellent category for example and your
number just summarizes and gives you a
really good indicator of where you sit
on that banding. And you know that
that's how a lender will really look at
that information and say okay you know
what we do think that's good and that's
how we base that number.
Okay so you're out of 999 Equifax and
TransUnion are out of different numbers.
So Equifax I think is out of a thousand
and TransUnion is slightly lower out of
Yeah. Well don't compare them side by
side. It's good to check them all and
you can do it for free. So you know
please do uh but don't compare them side
by side and say right my experience
score is this why is my transunion score
so low just view them individually and
see how you sit on the banding with
those credit reference agencies.
Okay and do any other organizations have
credit scores for us? I for example does
my bank have a credit score for me? Does
my mortgage holder have a credit score
for me? Are there other numbers around
the place that aren't with these three
main unions?
Yes. Well, just to make this, you know,
even easier for you, there are different
numbers, but you will not ever see those
numbers. The only time the the other
number is generated for you is when you
apply for something. So, you'll apply,
they will check the information on your
credit report, plus your application
form information. So, really, your
affordability, your salary, dependence,
other expenses, and so on. And perhaps
if you bank with them already, their own
information. And at that point you
apply, they'll generate a score for you.
That's the score that determines do you
get accepted or not? What's the interest
rate going to be? What's the limit going
to be? But they don't tell you what that
number is. So, you know, you'll know you
were good enough if you get accepted and
get the good rates. You'll know you were
borderline if maybe the interest rate
goes up a bit at the end or you don't
quite get the limit you want.
Okay. All right. Very useful. Then I
suppose the next obvious question to ask
is how are those scores built? What goes
into the building of the score? What
what are the agency is looking at?
The score is built on lender feedback.
So they tell us the credit reference
agencies what's important. So you know
what's important in terms of your
payment history if you've made them on
time or in terms of the amount of debt
you have, missed payments, court
judgments. There's lots of information
that goes into calculating the score,
but it's based primarily on h how we
work with and experience hundreds of
lenders to figure out exactly what's
important and how we build that score.
Okay. So, your score will be good if you
have borrowed money, always paid it back
on time effectively.
Yeah. A good track record of managing
credit. So, you've you've had some sort
of credit agreements in the past. you've
paid them on time and po possibly in an
ideal world you have paid them off and
closed them successfully and then that
that's kind of how you build your track
record of managing credit well and that
leads to generally a good score. There
are other things that obviously impact
it. So you know not just that but how
much current debt you are in for example
will have a big influence if you've got
credit cards how much you're borrowing
on those and how close you are to the
limit and so on. So your current debt
levels have a big impact on your score
as well. But the history is really
important.
Okay. I think there's an obvious
question that comes out of that. I I
want to ask the obvious question first
and then move on to asking you what
makes your credit rating bad. So the
first question is if you are Tala for
example, you asked us this question and
you're in your early 20ies and you have
never borrowed money before that means
you don't have a credit score at all or
it means you have a bad credit score.
It's uh no it doesn't necessarily mean
you have a bad credit score. So they're
kind of what we call a thin file. So
where you just have very limited
information, which means the lender can
make very little judgment about how well
you'll manage credit. So you know, we
always kind of talked then about the
process of building your credit history.
And it's kind of step-by-step process of
getting some sort of information onto
your credit report, managing it well
through those credit accounts, and then
building it over time. Is there anything
you can do to boost that low? I mean,
something I always hear about is making
sure you're on the electoral register or
the voters role and exactly,
you know, because I suppose the first
time you you get credit, you don't want
to be going for a mortgage. I mean, does
having a mobile phone contract help all
of these sorts of things?
Yeah, it does actually. And it's a good
point because in terms of building it,
let's say almost from scratch, getting
on the electoral role is probably the
first thing that I would suggest people
do. So, wherever they can, of course,
get registered on the electoral role.
That's your first bit. Your next bit is
having a bank account. It doesn't matter
if it's got an overdraft, but as long as
you've got a bank account, it'll add
some information on there, but don't
have any problems with it if you can.
So, try not to go into unarranged
borrowing and so on. That can cause an
issue. And then the next stage would
kind of be thinking about getting a
credit card. And that's because if you
use that in the right way, uh, and
perhaps we'll talk about that in a
moment, is they're quite easy to get.
And if you use them in the right way and
pay them off in full, you don't pay the
interest on it. And suddenly you've got
a couple of accounts plus the electoral
role, you're building up some positive
information on your credit report. So
that's a great way to start that
process.
I think we better go straight into what
is using a credit card the right way. I
mean, I think we would we would think
using a credit card the right way is
buying stuff with it, paying it off, not
paying any interest, but you you said
that already. Is there something else
involved in the right way?
Well, it's just to do with the balance
and how you use it on there. And of
course, this is the right way for, you
know, me as a credit reference agency,
let's say, because what we want to see
and what a lender likes to see is a very
low balance, but an active account. So
the way to do that is spending a few
pounds every month on something you
would have bought anyway. So try not to
buy something that you wouldn't have
wanted to buy normally. That's how you
kind of get into problems. But spend it
on something the food shop once a month,
something like that. Pay it off in full
every month so you don't pay the
interest on it. And so if you keep the
balance low, you keep it active, you
don't pay the interest, that's a great
way to keep your credit card running. Of
course, there are people who use credit
cards to do their normal spend on.
That's because they might get rewards,
points, things like that on it, and
there's nothing wrong with that. But if
you're spending a large amount or
getting very close to the limit every
month, then that can show on your credit
report, and that could affect your
credit score. So, you probably want to
avoid that right before you apply for
something important. That's interesting
because this is another thing I've read
about this idea of not wanting to do too
many things like if you go to the
personal finance websites and people
often talk about how you apply for a new
bank account so you can get the
switching bonuses every six months or
something like that. But then they sort
of say but don't do that if you're about
to apply for either a mortgage or a
personal loan or a big credit card. Can
you give us an idea of what the kind of
leeway is and that sort of stuff? Is
there any sort of guide as to what's a
less less of a big deal and what's more
important to avoid?
Yeah, so there's lots to that question,
but the first part is we generally say
because when you apply for credit, it
pops up on your credit report and it
could lower your credit score. And so we
say keep those to a minimum where you
can. So probably a couple every few
months is a good idea. And so, you know,
that's why we say probably a couple of
months, 2, 3 months before you apply for
something bigger, like the mortgage, for
example, you want to avoid applying for
other types of credit, just so you don't
have those applications pop on. But the
other part to your question is if you're
applying for something that,
you know, has a value to it. So, let's
say you you're taking out a loan or um
potentially even using buy now pay later
or something that would add a balance of
debt to your credit report. You again
might want to avoid that before applying
for something big just because of that
will then impact into your
affordability, how much you're currently
borrowing, those kinds of things.
Yeah. One quick thing there. You
mentioned buy now pay later. What is the
status of that at the moment? And
because I I've not stayed fully a breast
of this and I remember the sort of clown
style stuff wasn't really being kept an
eye on and how's how's that changing or
or what's going on with that?
Yeah, so it's an interesting question
but that there are buy now pay later
lenders who are sharing with credit
reference agencies now. Cler being one
of them. They share their information
with us and some of the others do with
the other credit reference agencies as
well. It doesn't factor into the credit
score we give you yet because the
sharing is so new. And there is
regulation that is kind of proposed and
coming down the line which may mean that
possibly next year 2026 there they will
be regulated to share all by now pay
later accounts with credit reference
agencies. So that might come down the
line but it may be that if you use
certain ones they will share with a
credit reference agency at the moment.
So you'll see those accounts pop onto
your credit report. So, let's talk about
what makes your credit rating bad. What
are the things that actively make it
bad? I mean, I'm assuming things like
having a counter court judgment against
you, a bankruptcy, an IVA, um that that
kind of thing, but is there is there
anything else that will actively make it
bad that might not be immediately
obvious to people like us?
Yeah, of course. So, these obviously are
the things to try and avoid where
possible? We've talked about applying
for credit. So, you know, lots of
applications in a short space of time,
that's likely to drop your credit score.
Um, if you've got lots of new accounts
as well. So, we we calculate the average
age of your account. So, really what
we're saying is longunning accounts are
good. Loads of new accounts can kind of
impact your credit score quite
significantly, especially if they're
under a year old. And then the next part
is payment history. This a really big
part of calculating your score. So
missed payments, even one of them could
impact your credit score by quite a lot.
So, you know, really important to have
the direct debit set up, make sure
things are paid on time. Even the mobile
phone contract, you know, the the
smaller bills that you think actually,
you know what, that's not going to have
much of an impact, it will still impact
your credit report if you miss it.
Does that include your electricity bill
and your water bill and all that sort of
thing?
Yes, they are shared with credit
reference agencies as well. So, you
know, if you're missing those payments
and and also incurring debt for missing
those payments, yes, that will show on
the credit report as well. You talked
about county court judgments. So, court
judgments, uh, anything to do with
insolveny like an IVA or bankruptcy will
obviously have a significant impact on
your credit score. But the biggest thing
that actually does have an impact on
your score is what we call a defaulted
account. So, that's an account where you
haven't paid it in probably somewhere
around 3 to 6 months. and the lender has
then closed the account with an
outstanding amount set as a default
stays on your report for 6 years from
that point and that has a really big
impact on getting credit. So, you know,
my biggest advice actually in in that
scenario is if you're missing payments
or you're going to miss payments and
you're in that place where you will go
on the road to potentially a default is
speak to the lender straight away. try
and set some sort of payment arrangement
up that at least stops it going to a
default. Or as well as that, speak to a
free debt advice provider, your step
change pay plan, someone like that who
can really help sort out, you know, your
kind of finances and budget and so on
and find the right solution for you.
Let's say I'm applying for a mortgage
and my credit score with Experian with
all of them is not excellent but very
good. What's the difference in the
interest rate that I'm likely to get
offered for a mortgage?
That's a that's a very difficult
question to answer. So, well, let's
don't focus on that too much. And the
reason I say that is like I explained
earlier, what happens is the lender
doesn't see the score that we give you.
They see the information on the credit
report, but they use that in conjunction
with the your affordability information.
So, you might have a huge deposit. I'm
sure you've been saving for a long time.
So, you've got that. Your salary is
great. your other expenses are minimal
and that you know together they
calculate that and give you their own
score and that might mean that you get
you know a a very very good interest
rate if there is an issue with
affordability or with negative
information on your credit report.
That's where you might start to see the
interest rate is getting a little bit
higher when you apply. But that's down
to each individual lender, how they
judge it, how they you know assess that
score and you know what rate they give
you at the end.
You're saying that there may be no
difference between the interest rate I'm
offered if I'm very good or excellent
and still so subjective, isn't it? It's
uh well I wouldn't say subjective
because it's slightly so I guess it's
scientific in the sense that you know
there's just it's a lot of data to look
at and judge but each lender will be
slightly different in how they assess
it. So I don't want people to get hung
up on the fact that they're 12 points
away from being in the excellent
category because that will have very
minimal impact on you know how the
lender judges the information. It's
really about making sure your credit
reports in a good place and then
obviously they factor in the other
information as well.
Yeah, it's a bit late for that John
Bruners because we are target driven
people and John and I the second we
finish here we'll be going online and
we'll be trying to find out what our
score is at each one and if it doesn't
matter how far we are offent we're both
going for it and it will be a
competition. I'm going to be excellent
long before John. Right, John?
Oh absolutely, absolutely.
Maybe he's excellent already. I don't
know. We'll be finding out in the next
10 minutes. And the only other thing I
wanted to check, John, was see if you do
have bad credit. How do you repair that?
Like say you've had, I don't know, a
dodgy kind of like, you know, kind of
20ies, but now you're a responsible
adult. Um, what's what what should you
start with? Well, look, the the good
news I'd start with is that generally
information on your report stays for six
years. So, there's always light at the
end of the tunnel if there's something
negative. The thing I would say is key
is just keeping on track. So you might
have some negative stuff. It's about
okay, it can that negative stuff be
brought up to date if you've been
missing payments and kind of turn that
into a positive, keep that running well.
And depending on what it is, it might
mean that you focus on other accounts.
So you those basics that we talked about
earlier, you know, having the bank
account, maybe having the credit card,
and just focusing on those and keeping
them running well on time, paid on time,
balances low, and then at some point the
the other negative information might
drop off the report and it has less of a
negative impact on your score over time.
So it's kind of just focusing on doing
good things while you can and with what
you can and then it will start to
improve over time. The other thing I
would say as well is you know kind of
when we're talking about the negative
bit as well in the applying for credit
process is actually there are lots of
services available to search for credit.
So primarily credit cards, loans, car
finance and in a way for mortgages as
well but use comparison sites and
eligibility services to check for
credit. So we've got one. There are lots
of them out there and the reason you use
those is they don't impact your credit
score when you do the search. It's a bit
like searching for house insurance
online. They're soft searches. Don't
impact your credit score, but they will
give you a very good idea of who will
accept you and what kind of deals you
can get. And you could even get
preapproved as well, which is always a
delight to know before you actually
apply. So, you know, if anyone does if
anyone's looking for credit, even if
they're in a good place or they have
negative information, it's a great place
to do your kind of credit research. I
know you said about admin earlier, it's
more admin, but it means that, you know,
you get a really good idea of who you
should approach rather than just
applying to anyone who you've seen and
and possibly getting refused.
If I can look up my credit score this
easily, can other people look up my
credit score?
No.
Why not? So when you say open an account
with a credit reference agency, we go
through lots of checks to make sure it's
you that is setting up an account to
check your credit report and score. We
verify information across public record
information like electoral role account
information to verify that it's
definitely you. And if there's any
issues with that, we also go through
further checks to check your ID
documents and possibly bills or
statements as well to make sure that we
do not show anyone else your
information.
Okay, good. I'm a little nervous about
my electricity bill now and everyone
else looking it up. So, I think we're
all good.
John, thank you so much for being with
us today. We really appreciate it.
No, glad to be here.
Yes, thank you.
Thanks for listening to this week's
Marin Talks Your Money. If you like our
show, rate, review, and subscribe
wherever you listen to podcasts. Also,
be sure to follow me and John on X or
Twitter, MarinSw, and John Steepex. This
episode was produced by Samadi Tala
Amardi and Moses Andam. Production
support and sound design by Blake
Maples. Questions and comments on this
show and all our shows are always
welcome. Our show email is
meramoney@bloomberg.net.
[Music]

cleanText:
[Music]
Bloomberg Audio Studios podcasts, radio, news.

Welcome to Merryn Talks Your Money, the personal finance edition of Merryn Talks Money. In these bonus podcasts, we talk about the best strategies for making the most of your money. I'm Merryn Somerset Webb, and with me senior reporter and money distilled author John Stepek. Hi John.

Hi Merryn.

Right, this week we are tackling a topic suggested by Tala, an apprentice here at Bloomberg who's been working on our team the last few months. Tala is in her early 20s and says the surprisingly frequent topic among her friends is credit scores.

I don't really have a credit history yet. How would my credit score be determined? What factors go into determining my credit score? And how do I even check my credit score? I've noticed that when I check my credit score on different websites, they vary. Why is that?

I'm a bit lost by this one. I literally do not remember ever talking about credit scores in my 20ies, John.

Um, no. But then we were privileged cuz the '90s were a much better time for young people in general. We didn't have to worry about money, did we? Really, cuz everything was so cheap.

Yeah, we could buy houses.

Yeah, we could buy houses.

On the plus side, the fact that that Tala and her friends are caring about credit scores, maybe they're taking out mortgages. We'll talk about that later. Anyway, so the question is, how do credit scores work? What are they? Do I have one? Do I have several? How important is it? What does it mean? What affects it the most? And how do I make it good? So, lots of questions here, some of which John and I could answer alone, some of which we quite clearly couldn't. So, we brought an expert to help us go through all the basics of this subject, John Webb. John is the senior consumer affairs manager at Experian. John, thank you so much for joining us today.

Oh, glad to join. So right back at the beginning, what is a credit score?

There is not one credit score. So your credit score is a number that is given to you by a credit reference agency like Experian and there are others as well. Equifax and TransUnion are the other two. So there's three main credit reference agencies and we will all give you a number and it's a summary of the performance of your credit report. So all the information that's on there, how you've managed credit in the past 6 years or so and how much debt you are in for example right now and the number gives you a good indication of how a lender will judge the information on your credit report when you apply for credit.

Okay, so this is a number. What is a good number and what is a bad number?

Well, that's an interesting question because there is not one credit score. Don't judge the numbers side by side. Each credit reference agency will give you their own experiences out of 999. So we will give you a banding to say you know somewhere along the lines of you're somewhere in the good or very good or excellent category for example and your number just summarizes and gives you a really good indicator of where you sit on that banding. And you know that that's how a lender will really look at that information and say okay you know what we do think that's good and that's how we base that number.

Okay so you're out of 999 Equifax and TransUnion are out of different numbers. So Equifax I think is out of a thousand and TransUnion is slightly lower out of 710.

Yeah. Well don't compare them side by side. It's good to check them all and you can do it for free. So you know please do uh but don't compare them side by side and say right my Experian score is this why is my TransUnion score so low just view them individually and see how you sit on the banding with those credit reference agencies.

Okay and do any other organizations have credit scores for us? I for example does my bank have a credit score for me? Does my mortgage holder have a credit score for me? Are there other numbers around the place that aren't with these three main unions?

Yes. Well, just to make this, you know, even easier for you, there are different numbers, but you will not ever see those numbers. The only time the the other number is generated for you is when you apply for something. So, you'll apply, they will check the information on your credit report, plus your application form information. So, really, your affordability, your salary, dependence, other expenses, and so on. And perhaps if you bank with them already, their own information. And at that point you apply, they'll generate a score for you. That's the score that determines do you get accepted or not? What's the interest rate going to be? What's the limit going to be? But they don't tell you what that number is. So, you know, you'll know you were good enough if you get accepted and get the good rates. You'll know you were borderline if maybe the interest rate goes up a bit at the end or you don't quite get the limit you want.

Okay. All right. Very useful. Then I suppose the next obvious question to ask is how are those scores built? What goes into the building of the score? What what are the agencies looking at?

The score is built on lender feedback. So they tell us the credit reference agencies what's important. So you know what's important in terms of your payment history if you've made them on time or in terms of the amount of debt you have, missed payments, court judgments. There's lots of information that goes into calculating the score, but it's based primarily on how we work with and experience hundreds of lenders to figure out exactly what's important and how we build that score.

Okay. So, your score will be good if you have borrowed money, always paid it back on time effectively.

Yeah. A good track record of managing credit. So, you've you've had some sort of credit agreements in the past. you've paid them on time and possibly in an ideal world you have paid them off and closed them successfully and then that that's kind of how you build your track record of managing credit well and that leads to generally a good score. There are other things that obviously impact it. So you know not just that but how much current debt you are in for example will have a big influence if you've got credit cards how much you're borrowing on those and how close you are to the limit and so on. So your current debt levels have a big impact on your score as well. But the history is really important.

Okay. I think there's an obvious question that comes out of that. I I want to ask the obvious question first and then move on to asking you what makes your credit rating bad. So the first question is if you are Tala for example, you asked us this question and you're in your early 20ies and you have never borrowed money before that means you don't have a credit score at all or it means you have a bad credit score.

It's uh no it doesn't necessarily mean you have a bad credit score. So they're kind of what we call a thin file. So where you just have very limited information, which means the lender can make very little judgment about how well you'll manage credit. So you know, we always kind of talked then about the process of building your credit history. And it's kind of step-by-step process of getting some sort of information onto your credit report, managing it well through those credit accounts, and then building it over time. Is there anything you can do to boost that low? I mean, something I always hear about is making sure you're on the electoral register or the voters role and exactly, you know, because I suppose the first time you you get credit, you don't want to be going for a mortgage. I mean, does having a mobile phone contract help all of these sorts of things?

Yeah, it does actually. And it's a good point because in terms of building it, let's say almost from scratch, getting on the electoral role is probably the first thing that I would suggest people do. So, wherever they can, of course, get registered on the electoral role. That's your first bit. Your next bit is having a bank account. It doesn't matter if it's got an overdraft, but as long as you've got a bank account, it'll add some information on there, but don't have any problems with it if you can. So, try not to go into unarranged borrowing and so on. That can cause an issue. And then the next stage would kind of be thinking about getting a credit card. And that's because if you use that in the right way, uh, and perhaps we'll talk about that in a moment, is they're quite easy to get. And if you use them in the right way and pay them off in full, you don't pay the interest on it. And suddenly you've got a couple of accounts plus the electoral role, you're building up some positive information on your credit report. So that's a great way to start that process.

I think we better go straight into what is using a credit card the right way. I mean, I think we would we would think using a credit card the right way is buying stuff with it, paying it off, not paying any interest, but you you said that already. Is there something else involved in the right way?

Well, it's just to do with the balance and how you use it on there. And of course, this is the right way for, you know, me as a credit reference agency, let's say, because what we want to see and what a lender likes to see is a very low balance, but an active account. So the way to do that is spending a few pounds every month on something you would have bought anyway. So try not to buy something that you wouldn't have wanted to buy normally. That's how you kind of get into problems. But spend it on something the food shop once a month, something like that. Pay it off in full every month so you don't pay the interest on it. And so if you keep the balance low, you keep it active, you don't pay the interest, that's a great way to keep your credit card running. Of course, there are people who use credit cards to do their normal spend on. That's because they might get rewards, points, things like that on it, and there's nothing wrong with that. Yeah, so there's lots to that question, but the first part is we generally say because when you apply for credit, it pops up on your credit report and it could lower your credit score. This a really big part of calculating your score. So missed payments, even one of them could impact your credit score by quite a lot. Yes, they are shared with credit reference agencies as well. So, court judgments, uh, anything to do with insolvency like an IVA


Or bankruptcy will obviously have a significant impact on your credit score. But the biggest thing that actually does have an impact on your score is what we call a defaulted account. So, that's an account where you haven't paid it in probably somewhere around 3 to 6 months, and the lender has then closed the account with an outstanding amount set as a default. Stays on your report for 6 years from that point, and that has a really big impact on getting credit. So, you know, my biggest advice actually in that scenario is if you're missing payments or you're going to miss payments and you're in that place where you will go on the road to potentially a default is speak to the lender straight away. Try and set some sort of payment arrangement up that at least stops it going to a default. Or as well as that, speak to a free debt advice provider, your step change pay plan, someone like that who can really help sort out, you know, your kind of finances and budget and so on and find the right solution for you.
